title: Provide a guide to standard traits in the documentation

labels.name: C-enhancement
labels.description: Category: An issue proposing an enhancement or a PR with one.

labels.name: E-medium
labels.description: Call for participation: Experience needed to fix: Medium / intermediate

labels.name: A-docs
labels.description: Area: documentation for any part of the project, including the compiler, standard library, and tools

body:
When learning Rust, it can be difficult to get acquainted with the standard Rust traits, as their documentation is scattered in many places.

Some are introduced gradually over the course of the Book, some are reviewed in more details in the Nomicon, some are discussed in the Reference, and most are just scattered around the std crates (std::ops, std::marker and many others) with a description that ranges from fine (e.g. Clone) to minimalistic (e.g. bitwise operations).

This makes it difficult for Rust newcomers to properly implement new types in libraries, as picking which traits they should implement can be a challenge. Even experts seem to get it wrong, as well-respected libraries like num_complex and nalgebra can be missing common traits like MulAssign or Sum.

I think it would be nice to have, somewhere in the standard Rust documentation, a centralized glossary of standard Rust traits which provides a short description of each of them and links to more extensive documentation whenever necessary (e.g. to the Nomicon for Send/Sync).

A very good starting point would be https://llogiq.github.io/2015/07/30/traits.html . Here is what I would do before integration in the standard documentation:

- Get the author's permission to reuse the original text: no need to reinvent the wheel :)
- Add a lexicographically ordered index at the top or in a sidebar.
- Decide how much detail we want to put in there, versus how much we want to link to more detailed references like the llogiq blog post.
- Clarify that "Rem" may not work like C/++ developers would expect.
- Add documentation of the XyzAssign traits, Product/Sum, and any other trait we can find in the std reference which is not covered there already.
- Maybe add or link to a more extensive discussion of Rust iterators when discussion the various Iterator traits.

Is there anything else that comes to someone's mind?
